poem:
Title: "An Ode to Ancient Life"

Beneath the dusky cloak of Devon's crest,
Stand sentinels from primordial rest.
Hardened whispers of the Calamophyton's tale,
Weathered, wizened in a sandstone veil.
As silent as an echo in the fossilised night,
They mark the ages with their stoic might.
Ancient sentinels of time, etched in stone
Speak quietly of worlds we've never known.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "World’s oldest fossilised trees discovered along Devon and Somerset coast The world’s oldest fossilised trees, dating back 390m years, have been found in the high sandstone cliffs along the Devon and Somerset coast. The fossilised trees are the oldest ever found, roughly 4m years older than the previous record holder, which was found in New York state. The fossilised trees, known as Calamophyton, would resemble palm trees if seen from a distance, but were a". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
